intro: Salvia hyptoides, commonly known as the mountain sage, is a perennial shrub native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its gray-green, hairy foliage and spikes of violet-blue flowers that bloom in summer. The plant belongs to the mint family (Lamiaceae), which is known for its aromatic properties and square stems. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it suitable for xeriscaping in arid environments. Its compact growth habit and ornamental value make it a popular choice for rock gardens and native plant collections.
